comments:
Reporter: Tony Liu
OS: RHEL WS 3.0 -gtk
Language: KOR
Build level: wswb-30M8-200403311308
JDK Version: IBM JDK 1.4.2 Beta
Test case #: VE
Summary: DBCS:  Can not render visual part  in the graph viewer when create a 
Visual Class. 

Steps to recreate problem:
1- Create a Java project and select it in the Navigator view. 
2- Select File-->New-->Visual Class, create a Visual Class.
3- Verify that the Visual Editor opens with the visual part on the top in the 
graph viewer .
<<Error>>     
        The Visual Editor opens but  visual part do not render properly on the 
top in the graph viewer. 
(ve.jpg) 
<<Expected Result>>
        The Visual Editor opens with the properly rendered visual part on the 
top in the graph viewer.

Created an attachment (id=9281)
The picture of the bug

The picture of the bug

Peter - can you see the attachment ?  For me the JPG won't show properly so 
it's hard to see what the problem is
Leading - what is the difference between the expected result and what you 
see ?  Who eoes the class you create have as their superclass ?

Please provide more information with regard to this problem. 
What class did you extend in the New Visual Class wizard? JFrame, JPanel, etc.?
Please attach the .log file from the .metadata directory of your workspace.
Does this problem occur on RHEL WS 3.0 Linux GTK only? Or have you seen the 
same problem on Windows?
Thank you...

Hi Peter:
     I want to extend a JFrame class in the New Visual Class wizard,but have a 
new bug#59414 about VE on build I20040413-200404191247. I have to verify 
bug#57711 on build Eclipse M8.I find this problem occur on RHEL WS 3.0 Linux 
GTK only. More information please see the Attachment.thanks

message log in command window.

message log  in command window.I don't find have .metadata  in workbench.
Was successful in recreating the problem... investigating.

This isn't a problem with the VE, and not specific to DBCS.  It's actually a
problem with the IBM JRE 1.4.2 Beta... it won't run any Swing or AWT code on
RHEL 3.0.  If you switch your JRE to the Sun 1.4.2 it works fine. To test this
theory compile and run this code with the IBM JRE:

import javax.swing.*;                                                          
                    
public class Test2 {                                                           
        public static void main(String args[]) {
                JFrame myFrame = new JFrame("Hello");
                myFrame.setDefaultCloseOperation(JFrame.EXIT_ON_CLOSE);
                myFrame.setSize(300,300);
                myFrame.show();
        }
}

Running it (even with English) will result in the following exception:

[jmyers@jvetest Testing]$ ../../jre/bin/java Test2
Exception in thread "main" java.lang.UnsatisfiedLinkError:
/home/jmyers/wswb/eclipse/jre/bin/libfontmanager.so: libstdc++-libc6.2-2.so.3:
cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory
        at java.lang.ClassLoader$NativeLibrary.load(Native Method)
        at java.lang.ClassLoader.loadLibrary0(ClassLoader.java:2119)
        at java.lang.ClassLoader.loadLibrary(ClassLoader.java:1985)
        at java.lang.Runtime.loadLibrary0(Runtime.java:823)
        at java.lang.System.loadLibrary(System.java:907)
        at sun.security.action.LoadLibraryAction.run(LoadLibraryAction.java:75)
        at java.security.AccessController.doPrivileged1(Native Method)
        at java.security.AccessController.doPrivileged(AccessController.java:286)
        at sun.awt.font.NativeFontWrapper.<clinit>(NativeFontWrapper.java:67)
        at sun.awt.X11GraphicsEnvironment.initDisplay(Native Method)
        at sun.awt.X11GraphicsEnvironment.<clinit>(X11GraphicsEnvironment.java:168)
        at java.lang.Class.forName1(Native Method)
        at java.lang.Class.forName(Class.java:179)
        at
java.awt.GraphicsEnvironment.getLocalGraphicsEnvironment(GraphicsEnvironment.java:89)
        at java.awt.Window.init(Window.java:265)
        at java.awt.Window.<init>(Window.java:309)
        at java.awt.Frame.<init>(Frame.java:429)
        at javax.swing.JFrame.<init>(JFrame.java:225)
        at Test2.main(Test2.java:6)

We didn't run into this problem before because we were not testing with the IBM
JRE on RHEL 3.0.  Not sure if this affects other Linux distros as well.

Please open this problem with the team responsible for the IBM JRE 1.4.2.

Note: java -version on the JRE included in wswb-30M8

java version "1.4.2"
Java(TM) 2 Runtime Environment, Standard Edition (build 1.4.2)
Classic VM (build 1.4.2, J2RE 1.4.2 IBM build cxia32dev-20040322 (JIT enabled:
jitc))

Gili Mendel has sent a note to John/Nik .... "this is a beta IBM driver... I 
need someone to open a JRE bug and track it.  I have no access to the JRE's bug 
tracking process."

we did not see this problem in wswb 30 with IBM JDK 1.4.2 after installing 
libstdc++-libc6.2-2.so.3 library on RHEL 30.    
We also did not see this problem if we use Sun JDK 1.4.2 instead. Please open a 
bug to Hursley for this IBM JDK 1.4.2 problem.
Nick (teshiman@ca.ibm.com) will open a defect on the JRE

No one on the IES NL team nor the VE team has been able to recreate this 
problem on recent IES drivers.  Has anyone else?  I don't think we have a bug 
in Eclipse, the JRE or RHEL.  Or, if we did before, we don't anymore.

This is interesting.... as it seems (need to verify) that using -Xj9 on the IBM
JRE resolves this.  This would be a good thing, but the reason this defect was
raised, and was also encountered by tests, is that it is not obvious that -Xj9
is a requirenment.

I'm still able to recreate this problem, even with the -Xj9 command argument.

Please run the command "rpm -q compat-libstdc++-7.3" on your test box, if it
comes back saying that that package is intstalled, the problem will not show up.
 If it reports that not being installed (as it isn't installed by default on
RHEL) the problem with the JRE will be evident.
